Conviction checker

Check if your conviction may affect licensing. This tool provides guidance based on the Common Standards policy.

Date you finished your sentence (prison release, probation end, fine paid, etc.)

Important: This is guidance only. Each case is assessed individually based on all circumstances. Contact the licensing team at licensing@gloucester.gov.uk to discuss your specific situation.

Full conviction policy

Document: Common Standards for Licensing Hackney Carriage and Private Hire Drivers in Gloucestershire

Status: Adopted September 2021

Applies to: All Gloucestershire licensing authorities

General principles

  • Purpose: Protect public from harm
  • Starting point: Recent serious offences normally preclude licensing
  • Rehabilitation: Passage of time and evidence of reform considered
  • Each case: Individual circumstances considered
  • Burden: Applicant must demonstrate fitness

Typical time periods from completion of sentence

These are guidelines - each case assessed individually

Offence type Minimum period
Murder Never likely to be granted
Manslaughter 15 years
Serious violence 10 years
Sexual offences 10-15 years (many never granted)
Dishonesty 7 years
Drugs (supply/dealing) 10 years
Drink/drug driving 7 years
Violent disorder 10 years

Notification requirement

48-hour rule: Must notify council within 48 hours of being formally notified of:

  • Cautions
  • Convictions
  • Fixed penalties
  • Pending prosecutions
  • Arrests (if relevant to fitness)

Method: In writing to Licensing Authority

Failure to notify: Serious breach - may result in revocation

Frequently asked questions

Getting licensed

Can I drive a taxi with my ordinary car licence?

No - you need a hackney carriage or private hire driver licence from the council in addition to your DVLA driving licence.

What's the difference between taxi and private hire?

Taxis (hackney carriages) can be hailed in street and wait at ranks. Private hire must be pre-booked through operator. Different licences and rules apply.

See full comparison table

What if I have a criminal conviction?

Depends on type, seriousness and time elapsed. See Common Standards policy. Each case assessed individually on whether you are fit and proper person.

Use our conviction checker tool

Do I need a medical every year?

Every 5 years if under 65, annually if 65 or over, or sooner if medical condition develops.

Vehicle licensing

Can I use my licensed vehicle for personal use?

Yes, but insurance must cover personal use as well as hire and reward. Plates must remain fitted.

What are grandfather rights?

Existing hackney carriage licences for non-wheelchair accessible vehicles can continue and be transferred to new owner. New additional hackney carriage licences must be wheelchair accessible.

This protects existing licence holders while gradually increasing wheelchair accessible vehicles in the fleet.

Working as a driver

Can I work for Uber or Lyft?

These are private hire operators. You need:

  • Private hire driver licence
  • Your vehicle needs private hire vehicle licence
  • Operator (Uber/Lyft) needs operator licence

Important: All must be from Gloucester if operating in Gloucester.

Can I refuse a fare?

Hackney carriage: No except lawful excuse (e.g. safety concern, passenger abusive). Must stop if available and safe when hailed. Cannot refuse short journeys within district.

Private hire: Operator takes booking decision. Driver accepts bookings issued by operator.

If things go wrong

What if my licence expires?
Cannot work - illegal to drive licensed vehicle without current licence. Apply for renewal before expiry.
Can I drive in other areas?

Your Gloucester licence only valid for Gloucester-licensed vehicles and operators. Other areas require their licences.

What if I get points on my DVLA licence?
Must notify council within 48 hours. May affect fitness depending on circumstances.

Fit and proper person test explained

What is the test?

Legal basis: Common law test - not defined in statute

Applies to: All drivers, vehicle proprietors, and operators

The test question

"Without any prejudice, and based on the information before you, would you allow a person for whom you care, regardless of their condition, to travel alone in a vehicle driven by this person at any time of day or night?"

Burden of proof: Balance of probabilities (civil standard, not criminal)

Applicant burden: Applicant must satisfy council they are fit and proper

What we consider

1. Criminal convictions and cautions

Relevance: Type, seriousness, time elapsed, pattern

Key offences of concern:

  • Dishonesty - serious concern
  • Violence - serious concern
  • Sexual offences - extremely serious concern
  • Driving offences - relevant to competence
  • Drugs offences - serious concern
  • Discrimination - serious concern

Use conviction checker

2. Driving record

Relevance: Penalty points, endorsements, bans

Threshold: More than 3 current points requires careful consideration

Serious: Driving bans, dangerous driving, drink/drug driving

3. Honesty and integrity

Critical: False information on application is extremely serious

We check:

  • All convictions and cautions declared
  • Accurate residence history
  • Truthful about previous licence refusals/revocations
  • Timely notification of changes

4. Medical fitness

Standard: DVLA Group 2 (same as HGV/PCV drivers)

Relevance: Driving with passengers requires higher medical standard

Conditions: Diabetes, heart conditions, epilepsy, sight - carefully assessed

5. Competence

Evidenced by:

  • Driving assessment
  • Knowledge test
  • English language proficiency

6. Previous licensing history

NR3 database: National Register shows refusals/revocations by any UK authority

Pattern: Pattern of complaints or breaches indicates concerns

Decision making

Delegated authority: Licensing officers have delegated power for straightforward cases

Committee referral: Complex cases referred to Licensing Sub-Committee

Reasons for referral:

  • Serious criminal convictions
  • Previous refusals or revocations
  • Multiple concerns about fitness
  • Controversial or borderline cases

Ongoing requirement

You must remain fit and proper throughout licence period. Continuous duty to notify of any changes affecting fitness.

Review triggers:

  • New conviction or caution
  • Complaint about conduct
  • Driving offence or points
  • Safeguarding concern
  • Medical condition affecting fitness

Fees and charges

Financial year: 2025/26

Fee setting: Fees must recover reasonable costs - cannot make profit (Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976)

Covers: Administration of licences, vehicle inspections, control and supervision of trade

Review: Fees reviewed annually as part of budget process

Payment methods

  • Online (credit/debit card)
  • By phone (01452 396396)

Important: Cannot proceed without payment. Application fees not refundable if application refused.

Typical fees

Hackney carriage fares

Applies to: Hackney carriages only - private hire fares not regulated

Legislation: Section 65 Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976

Current tariff

Effective from: November 2024

Flag fall (initial charge when hiring) Set by tariff
Distance (per mile or fraction) Set by tariff
Waiting time Set by tariff
Extra passengers Typically ¬£0.30 each
Wheelchairs NO CHARGE
Guide/assistance dogs NO CHARGE
Vehicle soiling charge ¬£75
Download full tariff card (PDF)

Important rules

  • Cannot exceed: Cannot charge more than meter shows
  • Can charge less: Can agree lower fare with passenger
  • Tariff card: Must display current tariff card in vehicle
  • Christmas rates: Higher tariff typically applies Christmas/New Year period

Pre-agreed fares

When: Journey starting outside Gloucester where no tariff applies

Rule: Can agree fare in advance

Must not exceed: If no fare agreed, cannot exceed what Gloucester tariff would be

Legal framework

Primary legislation

Town Police Clauses Act 1847 (Hackney carriages)

Reference: 10 & 11 Vict. c.89

URL: legislation.gov.uk

What law requires: Local authorities must license hackney carriages and their drivers

Key provisions:

  • Section 37: No person to act as hackney carriage driver without licence
  • Section 40: Power to grant hackney carriage driver licences
  • Section 47: Proprietors must obtain vehicle licence
  • Section 68: Power to make bye-laws for hackney carriages

Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976 (Private hire)

Reference: c.57, Part II

URL: legislation.gov.uk

What law requires: District councils may adopt Part II to license private hire vehicles, drivers, and operators

Gloucester status: Gloucester City Council has adopted Part II

Key sections:

  • Section 48: Licensing of private hire vehicles
  • Section 51: Licensing of private hire drivers
  • Section 55: Licensing of private hire operators
  • Section 60: Suspension and revocation of vehicle licences
  • Section 61: Suspension and revocation of driver licences including immediate suspension powers for public safety
  • Section 62: Suspension and revocation of operator licences
  • Section 68: Fitness inspection of vehicles

Supporting legislation

  • Equality Act 2010: Requirements for wheelchair accessible vehicles and assistance dogs
  • Immigration Act 2016: Right to work checks for all licence applicants
  • Road Safety Act 2006: Enhanced DBS checks and immediate suspension powers
  • Deregulation Act 2015: Sub-contracting of private hire bookings between operators
  • Policing and Crime Act 2017: Enhanced safeguarding through NR3 database sharing
  • Health Act 2006: Prohibition of smoking in licensed vehicles

Government guidance

Statutory Taxi and Private Hire Vehicle Standards (July 2020)

Issued by: Department for Transport

Status: Statutory - councils must have regard to

URL: gov.uk

Key requirements:

  • Enhanced DBS checks for all drivers
  • Information sharing through NR3 database
  • Common law fit and proper person test
  • Safeguarding training
  • Whistleblowing policies

Taxi and Private Hire Vehicle Licensing: Best Practice Guidance (November 2023)

Issued by: Department for Transport

Status: Guidance - councils should consider

URL: gov.uk

Key topics:

  • Licensing duration (3 years standard)
  • Medical standards (DVLA Group 2)
  • Knowledge tests
  • Vehicle standards
  • Enforcement approaches

How we use your personal information

When you apply for a taxi or private hire licence, we collect and use your personal information. This explains what we do with it and your rights.

Data controller

Gloucester City Council is the data controller

Data Protection Officer: dataprotection@gloucester.gov.uk

Address: Data Protection Officer, Gloucester City Council, Eastgate Management Suite, Eastgate Street, Gloucester, GL1 1PA

What information we collect

Personal data

  • Name, date of birth, address
  • Contact details
  • National Insurance Number
  • Driving licence number
  • Photograph

Special category data

This is sensitive information protected by stronger safeguards
  • Criminal convictions and offences (DBS)
  • Health information (medical certificates)

Licensing data

  • Application details
  • Licence history
  • Compliance and enforcement records
  • Complaint records

Why we collect it and our legal basis

Data type Legal basis Purpose
Licensing data Legal obligation Taxi licensing is a statutory function - we must do it by law
Criminal records (DBS) Substantial public interest Prevention and detection of crime, safeguarding
NR3 database sharing Legitimate interest Public safety

Who we share your information with

We share your data to protect public safety and comply with legal duties.

National Register (NR3)

What we share: Refusals and revocations

Why: Prevent unsuitable persons being licensed elsewhere

Legal basis: Legitimate interest in public safety

Police

What we share: Criminal matters and safeguarding concerns

Why: Law enforcement and safeguarding

Legal basis: Legal obligation and legitimate interest

Other licensing authorities

What we share: Licensing history via NR3

Why: Fit and proper assessment

Legal basis: Legitimate interest

Safeguarding agencies

Recipients: MASH, Adult safeguarding, Police, Children's services

Why: Concerns about risk of harm

Legal basis: Legal obligation to safeguard and vital interests

National Register (NR3) explained

The National Register of Taxi Licence Refusals and Revocations helps prevent unsuitable people being licensed.

When we check:

  • All new applications
  • All renewals

What we record if we refuse/revoke:

  • Name, DOB, address
  • National Insurance Number
  • Driving licence number
  • Decision taken and date
  • Reason for decision

How long: 11 years

How long we keep your information

Data type Retention period
Active licences Held while licence in force
Refused/revoked on NR3 11 years

Retention in line with council's corporate retention schedule and Information Commissioner guidance

Security measures

Technical: Secure IT systems, access controls, encryption where appropriate

Organisational: Staff training on data protection, confidentiality requirements, clear retention and disposal procedures

Enforcement

Compliance checks

Authorised officers: Licensing officers and police have powers to inspect and enforce

What we check:

  • Driver wearing badge
  • Plates correctly displayed
  • Insurance valid
  • Vehicle condition
  • Meter calibration (hackney carriage)
  • Pre-booking stickers (private hire)
  • Private hire not on ranks

Joint operations: Council and police conduct joint operations at ranks, stations, and nightlife areas

Suspension and revocation

Grounds for suspension/revocation

Drivers:

  • Convicted of offence involving dishonesty, violence or indecency
  • Non-compliance with legislation or licence conditions
  • Any other reasonable cause

Immediate suspension

Power: Section 61(2B) LG(MP)A 1976

Grounds: Interest of public safety

Effect: Licence suspended immediately - cannot work

Examples:

  • Serious criminal allegation
  • Safeguarding concern
  • Driving ban imposed
  • Serious breach of conditions

Standard suspension/revocation

Notice period: 21 days before taking effect

Representations: Licence holder can make representations

Hearing: May be heard by committee

Appeal: Can appeal to Magistrates Court within 21 days

Penalty points system

Gloucester operates penalty points for minor breaches

Threshold: 12 points in 12 months triggers committee referral

Examples:

  • Vehicle condition issues - 3-6 points
  • Not wearing badge - 6 points
  • Late notification of conviction - 6 points
  • Meter not calibrated - 6 points

Accumulation: Points accumulate - multiple breaches can lead to revocation

Criminal offences

Some breaches are criminal offences that can be prosecuted:

  • Driving without licence
  • Operating without operator licence
  • Private hire on taxi rank
  • Smoking in vehicle
  • Prolonging journey
  • Overcharging
  • Not wearing badge

Penalties: Fines, costs, criminal record
